title: 114_s1600
content: The Act titled "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. The Privacy Act provides exclusive remedies for covered persons to bring civil actions against designated Federal agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. Covered persons have the same rights and limitations as individuals under the Privacy Act. The Privacy Act provides remedies for individuals to pursue civil actions against Federal agencies for intentional disclosures. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" with the concurrence of other key officials. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if they have an agreement with the US for privacy protections or if the Attorney General determines it necessary. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if they have an agreement with the US for privacy protections or if the country has effectively shared information with the US for preventing criminal offenses. The designation can be revoked with the concurrence of the Secretary of State, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Secretary of Homeland Security. The concurrence of the Secretary of State, the Secretary of the Treasury, and the Secretary of Homeland Security can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if it is not complying with the agreement, no longer meets the requirements, or impedes information transfer. The Attorney General determines designated Federal agencies for information transfer purposes, excluding agencies other than the Department of Justice. The Attorney General can only designate agencies within the Department of Justice for information exchange with covered countries, requiring approval from the relevant agency head. The Attorney General can designate agencies within the Department of Justice for information exchange with covered countries if it is within the scope of an agreement or in the law enforcement interests of the United States. This determination is nonreviewable and must be published in the Federal Register. The Attorney General can designate agencies for information exchange with covered countries if it is in the law enforcement interests of the United States. Determinations made under this section are nonreviewable and must be published in the Federal Register. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over any claims arising under this section. Definitions in this Act include the meanings of "agency," "covered country," "covered person," and "covered record." The term "covered record" for a covered person has the same meaning as a record for an individual under section 552a of title 5, United States Code, once transferred to a designated Federal agency for investigative purposes. The term "individual" is defined in section 552a(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code. Nothing in this section waives any privilege or requires disclosure. The Act preserves privileges and does not require disclosure of classified information. The Act will take effect 90 days after its enactment.
